Governments around the world continue to try and deal with the COVID-19 pandemic. Money and support have been streamlined to frontline emergency services. This has meant that some facilities, such as sexual and reproductive clinics have been working with skeleton staff or have closed down altogether. However, the National Women’s Health Network, in coalition with other organizations, has urged the FDA to make the abortion pill available for people to access where they’ll be having the abortion—at home. The global pandemic doesn’t change the fact that people will need access to medical abortions.


The National Women’s Health Network worked alongside 80 organizations to write an open letter to the U.S Food and Drug Administration urging it to lift unnecessary medical restrictions so people could access the two pills needed to induce an abortion at home. Abortion Care Network, Human Rights Watch and Women’s Health Specialists were among some of the organizations that signed the letter. Cynthia A. Pearson, Executive Director of the National Women’s Health Network said, “these restrictions have never made medical sense, but now they risk making a global pandemic worse. In the midst of strict state stay-at-home orders, the FDA is requiring women and providers to leave their homes and travel long distances just to hand off a pill that could be mailed to their doorsteps or available at local pharmacies.”

Currently, the FDA requires that you have to pick up mifepristone in person from your clinician, clinic or hospital but you can wait to take it until you get home. This means people have to leave their houses to make, what can be a long journey, endangering themselves and the people around them. The early medical abortion always occurs at home, not it a medical setting. The letter reads, “these requirements have long harmed patients’ health by delaying or blocking access to medication abortion with no countervailing medical benefit. Now, in the midst of a public health emergency, these requirements are further endangering patients and straining the health system.” 


It continues, “solid research and nearly 20 years of clinical experience have demonstrated that these requirements are medically unnecessary...The FDA is putting the lives of pregnant people at risk. We urge you to take steps now to ensure that mifepristone remains a safe and effective form of abortion care during the crisis.”

In the UK the Department of Health confirmed that people needing an early medical abortion can take both pills at home, rather than travelling to a clinic to take the second pill. Speaking about the change Claire Murphy, the director of external affairs at British Pregnancy Advisory Service (BPAS), said, “this is a very safe and simple measure that will dramatically improve women’s access to care at this time of national crisis. We’re really pleased that the government has acted on this. It will make a huge difference to women’s health and wellbeing in the current climate.”

Research has found that even in times and places where abortion isn’t accessible, they still happen. However, the risk to the person undergoing the procedure is so much higher. According to the World Health Organisation providing women across the globe with access to safe and legal abortion services is essential to realizing and protecting their fundamental human rights.

In the letter the National Women’s Health Network and their co-signatories state “for many of these people, access to safe and effective mifepristone could be a lifeline, ensuring they receive prompt abortion care without having to visit a clinic, or even leave their homes.” Countries around the world have changed their abortion procedures in line with the CVOID-19 pandemic. The NWHN is urging the FDA to do the same.
